pageContext.title: It was once on the verge of global success, but this Chinese smartphone maker just went bust
pageContext.content:
If this is the first time you’ve heard of Chinese smartphone brand Gionee, then it’s also the last.

That’s because Gionee, which once sold as many as 32 million phones in a single year, has just gone bust.

Set up in 2002 in Shenzhen, China’s gadget city, Gionee was a maker of budget phones before Xiaomi made that cool. It also had some success overseas, becoming popular in price-sensitive markets such as India, Bangladesh, Vietnam, Thailand, the Philippines, and Nigeria.

Gionee’s rise and fall can be traced via data supplied to Tech in Asia by research firm IDC:

In 2016, the smartphone market had a “roller coaster year” – one in which Gionee soared while Apple and Samsung lost sales, suggesting it could be part of a new world order in which Chinese gadgets win over shoppers around the planet. Gionee shipped 2.2 percent of the 1.5 billion new smartphones snapped up that year, shifting over 32 million of its Android devices, and putting it close to cracking into the global top five phone brands.

Gionee’s decline is especially stark when seen alongside Huawei’s rise:

In China, Gionee plummeted from 7 percent of sales at the end of 2016 to an effective zero percent in the latest available figures for September 2018, IDC data shows.

The rise of Huawei, Vivo, Oppo, and a resurgent Xiaomi has squeezed smaller brands into an ever tinier margin in China over the past few years.

Back in 2014, China had around 500 smartphone makers, but that dropped to 100 two years later.

Photo credit: Gionee

Aside from the iron grip of China’s top four phone firms (plus Apple), smaller brands are getting crushed by the decline in the smartphone market for the past year and a half.

Casino cockup

Emails over the past few days to several Gionee staff resulted in “recipient does not exist” automated replies. The brand’s main websites are still online.

The brand, now officially liquidated after a Shenzhen court last week accepted its bankruptcy application, is saddled with losses of US$2.9 billion owed to 648 creditors.

Gionee chairman Liu Lirong early this year admitted his firm had overextended itself to the tune of US$1.4 billion after marketing and investments outlays.

Photo credit: Gionee

In a bizarre twist, Liu was last month exposed as a gambling addict, losing US$144 million of the firm’s cash in casinos.

At the last count, Gionee had 3,000 employees.

Elsewhere in China’s tech industry, Ofo, one of the top two bike-share apps, is weighing up bankruptcy over mounting losses.

seo.title: Death of a Chinese smartphone maker
